report_title: Industry at a Glance: Online Men's Clothing Sales
executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. The Online Men's Clothing Sales industry, which consists of sellers of men's apparel and accessories, excluding footwear, via e-commerce, has experienced rapid growth in recent years. Revenue has surged in response to favorable economic conditions such as higher discretionary income and low unemployment rates, contributing to a boost in discretionary spending. Revenue for online men's clothing companies is expected to climb at a CAGR of 9.8% to $29.3 billion through the end of 2024, including growth of 2.8% in 2024 alone, when profit is expected to hit 6.9% of revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Environmentalism Drives Demand for Sustainable Fashion
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Sustainable fashion has become a pinnacle concern for many US consumers as they become more troubled by the environmental footprint of clothing retailers and manufacturers. The demand for sustainable clothing has given players in this industry a new opportunity to serve a driven market of consumers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increased Digital Presence Spurs Growth in Men's Online Fashion
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Online Men's Clothing Sales industry experienced significant growth through the end of 2024. This was attributed to brighter economic conditions, including increased disposable income and decreased unemployment. With the proliferation of smart devices and robust broadband connections, e-commerce sales flourished and sales, especially of casual and sports clothing, saw a considerable boost.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Online Platforms Ignite Growth in Men's Clothing Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The various dynamics in the industry, along with rising income and a preference for virtual shopping, have bolstered the growth in online clothing sales. Lower operating and inventory expenses enable online sellers to offer a more comprehensive array of styles and sizes, one of the attractive aspects for shoppers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Trade Conditions Have Plagued the Industry During the Period
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Online men's clothing stores are not accounted for in the trade space, but their purchase of upstream inputs is undoubtedly affected by trade conditions. Through the end of 2024, sellers endured complex trade issues that weighed down revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the US workforce battled COVID-19, work-from-home became popular for most offices. However, as COVID restrictions become a thing of the past, many companies have laid out employee return-to-office plans. Returning to the office will support revenue in the coming years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Labor Costs in China Will Present a Significant Challenge for Manufacturing
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In previous years, China has shown growing signs of increasing labor costs. This is an issue for manufacturers since China is the global apparel manufacturing hub and most US apparel companies have outsourced their production to China.

Moving forward, slower growth is expected for online men's clothing sellers compared to the previous period. Growth for sellers is expected to normalize, following explosive growth caused by the pandemic.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increasing Interest Rates Pose Challenges for the Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The rising benchmark interest rate, as announced by the Federal Reserve in 2022 to combat inflation, will continue to be a speed bump for industries. As interest rates rise, financing becomes more expensive and consumers are likely to hide away funds instead of spending on discretionary goods, reducing the demand for goods sold by online stores.

industry_definition: This industry retails men's clothing through the internet. This includes online-only retailers as well as brick-and-mortar stores that have an online presence, but excludes the sale of men's footwear.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - increasing

key_trends: Amazon controls a dominant share of the industry. The company accounts for about 40.0% of all industry revenue, towering over its competition.
Smaller companies can become successful by cornering niche markets. Larger online sellers have a more difficult time doing this because they operate with less flexibility.
A massive influx of demand in 2020 presented companies with a unique opportunity for growth. Sellers that could capitalize on the shift to online shopping benefitted heavily.
Increasing interest rates are causing a crunch in demand for nondiscretionary clothing. Rising interest rates will continue to put pressure on the industry through the end of 2024.
The period was marked by heightened demand for men's casual clothes. Amazon was the biggest winner because of its massive size and breadth, especially during the pandemic.
Other companies struggle to exist in the market. Large companies like Amazon, Gap and Macy's dominate the competitive landscape. A company's best bet is finding a niche market to set up in.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Consumers under 25 account for the smallest market share, likely because of lower incomes and price sensitivity. Many in this segment have very limited spending power, which has been further reduced by recent inflation.

Individuals between the ages of 25 and 44 make up the largest share of internet shoppers, contributing more than a third of sales for online men's clothing sellers. With a steady income, awareness of fashion trends and willingness to spend on discretionary purchases, this group ensures a constant revenue stream for online men's fashion.

Consumers aged 45 to 64 significantly influence the online men's fashion market, taking up the second-largest revenue share. These high-income earners have boosted revenue, owing to their spending on premium items and increased adoption of mobile shopping.
Consumers over 65 contribute a small amount of demand, but they are typically brand and quality-driven consumers, who are willing to spend more.

products_and_services.product_description: Office and formal wear include suits, blazers, slacks, work shirts, ties, cufflinks, and occasion wear, which are generally more expensive.
Casual wear includes items like jeans, t-shirts, sweaters, collared shirts and casual outerwear; these items are typically less expensive and are purchased regularly by all types of consumers.
This category includes tennis, golf, jogging, swimming and other exercise apparel, in addition to sports team apparel such as licensed team jerseys and shirts.
This category includes items like underwear, socks, robes, hats, belts and other small accessories often considered essentials.

tier_1_suppliers: Men's & Boys' Apparel Wholesaling in the US
Freight Packing & Logistics Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The number of broadband connections in the United States
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The number of broadband connections in the United States represents the total number of internet connections with a speed of over 200 kilobits per second in at least one direction. As the number of broadband connections increases, more individuals have access to purchase men's clothing online, expanding the industry's market.

business_locations.location_description: The West region hosts the most industry establishments, with California leading the pack. The West region's access to major inspiration from one of the largest fashion hubs of the world, Los Angeles, boosts its visibility in the industry.

The Southeast region accounts for another significant share of the geographic disbursement of establishments. The dense population also provides sellers with a significant downstream market nearby. The state of Florida is becoming a hotbed for entrepreneurial and internet-based start-ups, resulting in its rank as the second-largest establishment holder.

The Mid-Atlantic houses the most prominent fashion capital in the US, New York City. Online sellers can take inspiration from the top designers while also having one of the best tech fields in the world. The region's dense urban population presents a large market for sellers.

The Mid-Atlantic houses the most prominent fashion capital in the US, New York City. Online sellers can take inspiration from the top designers while also having one of the best tech fields in the world. The region's dense urban population presents a large market for sellers. Sellers can also easily transport goods across these regions, keeping operating costs low.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FTC regulates e-commerce activities such as commercial email, online advertising and consumer privacy, ensuring businesses operate fairly and competently. For online men's clothing retailers, this means adhering to advertising standards, protecting customer data and using appropriate communication methods.

Data privacy regulations like the EU's GDPR and California's CCPA mandate strict protocols for handling customer data. Online retailers must obtain explicit consent for data collection, ensure data security and provide customers with rights to access or delete their information. Non-compliance can result in hefty fines.

E-retailers must navigate complex sales tax regulations, which vary by location. Recent rulings like the 2018 South Dakota v. Wayfair decision require online businesses to collect sales tax even in states where they don't have a physical presence. This ensures states receive due tax revenues while leveling the playing field between online and brick-and-mortar stores.

Increasingly, regulations encourage sustainable practices in manufacturing and selling apparel. Online retailers are expected to adhere to laws regarding waste management, sustainable sourcing of materials and reducing carbon footprints. Compliance can enhance brand image and appeal to environmentally-conscious consumers.

Employment and labor laws dictate fair treatment of workers within the industry. This includes ensuring compliance with minimum wage laws, providing safe working conditions and offering benefits where required. Ethical labor practices adhere to legal standards and enhance brand reputation and consumer loyalty.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Revenue volatility level is very high.
Industry assistance level is low and steady.
Competition level is high and increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Social media and design are two of the most important ways of differentiating products.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The two largest players control sizeable market share
concentration_points.concentration_description: Amazon and Macy's comprise about 50.0% of revenue for online men's clothing sellers in 2024.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Outside of Amazon, the Rest of the Industry is Fragmented
concentration_points.concentration_description: Overall, the industry is highly fragmented because of the ease of entry for smaller sellers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases represent the most significant cost for online men's clothing sellers. In 2024, purchases are expected to comprise 65.0% of revenue. Purchase costs have jumped as the price of cotton skyrocketed, which increased costs for online retailers. As global markets continue to recover, the price of cotton is expected to fall toward a more stable price, which will benefit online retailers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Labor Costs Shrink as Automation and Tech Increase in Presence
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are estimated to comprise 4.8% of revenue in 2024. Online retailers require less physical labor than a full-time employee, resulting in lower wages than traditional brick-and-mortar stores. Online men's clothing sellers have observed an increased role for automated machinery in fulfilling responsibilities previously carried out by staff. Still, labor is required for many vital tasks, including ordering, packaging and building out online platforms.

In 2024, profit is expected to account for 4.2% of revenue. Online sellers endure significant competition from international companies and brick-and-mortar retailers, resulting in online retailers often offering lower prices. While small and independent retailers are expected to have low profit because of competition, more prominent sellers can charge higher markups because of brand recognition and an established customer base.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This is a capital-intensive industry, requiring an e-commerce website and distribution methods. Online storefronts require capital to remain operational.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for clothing relies heavily on consumer confidence and household consumption habits. In recent years, consumer spending habits have been favorable, especially online retail sales. The pandemic provided a massive influx in demand for online retailers, as consumers remained inside to stop the spread of the virus. Volatility was not felt in all product segments, though casual clothing experienced a boom in demand, while dress clothes and formal wear tumbled as many consumers worked from home.

E-commerce stores are also reliant on internet accessibility and internet traffic volume. During the period, also partially influenced by COVID, e-commerce platforms saw an uptick in demand as more consumers had access to the internet.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: As time passes, new technology, sales tactics and payment methods have made online buying much more accessible. Consumers can easily connect to a seller using an internet connection and quickly input their payment information to make a purchase. As shopping online continues to become easier and more convenient, more consumers will switch to online shopping as their primary method. Still, the benefits of shopping at a physical location will continue to attract many consumers.

Artificial intelligence can be utilized in many ways in the e-commerce space. Visual search, personalization, chatbots and fraud detection are just a few technologies that have become popular in recent years.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market, or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Companies sell men's apparel and accessories but exclude footwear. The only sales are online sales of men's clothing and accessories.

FAQs.question: Do your company's advertising campaigns target a wide range of consumers?
FAQs.answer: Companies primarily target men since they are usually the ones buying men's clothes. Advertising campaigns are now more focused on targeting niche consumer markets than large universal marketing campaigns.

FAQs.question: Do you contract directly with manufacturers in order to reduce purchase costs?
FAQs.answer: Large companies like Nordstrom have contracts with brands manufacturing clothes. These supply contracts usually limit price increases and benefit department stores when they buy in bulk.

FAQs.question: Have rising input costs negatively impacted your company's sales?
FAQs.answer: Lowering input costs benefits industry companies because wholesale prices tend to drop, too. Profit profit usually expands with declining input prices.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to keep the most popular products in stock?
FAQs.answer: Companies log all merchandise leaving warehouses and online sales to keep track of sales and determine which items are most popular. Extra stock is purchased for hot-ticket products.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to the hike in online sales over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Due to the nature of the industry, companies have benefited from the hike in online sales over the past few years. Additionally, companies benefit from consumers becoming more comfortable with purchasing apparel online.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: During the shipping and packaging of products, workers are reminded of health and safety regulations. Facilities and warehouses are tested to see if they meet safety requirements.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: A Supreme Court decision was announced in June 2018, which permits states to require online retailers to collect sales tax. Amazon was already forced to do so in some states with Amazon Laws. Over the next five years, companies will see the effects of this legislation.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: The majority of apparel items are not that costly and therefore many companies do not offer financing options. However, an increasing number of retailers are implementing capabilities like Affirm, Klarna and AfterPay, which allow customers to pay overtime typically interest-free.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: Companies should look to leasing equipment and warehouse space if financing proves challenging.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that you have enough stock? How do you determine which products you should stock?
FAQs.answer: Companies must keep adequate stock on hand to ensure adequate quantities and selections of merchandise currently favored by consumers.

FAQs.question: How hard is it to anticipate consumer preferences? How quickly can you alter goods and services to best serve your customers?
FAQs.answer: To stay ahead of the competition, companies must stay ahead of constantly changing consumer preferences.

FAQs.question: Do you provide after-sales advice to its customers? How do you reward the loyalty of repeat customers?
FAQs.answer: Industry companies must provide superior customer service, including after-sales shipment tracking and offering refunds and exchanges, to maintain customer satisfaction and retention. Many customers opt to shop in-store to experience quality customer service, so online companies must incorporate superior sales staff into their workforce to retain customers.

FAQs.question: Do you experience strong competition from brick-and-mortar stores? Have you found a way to stay competitive?
FAQs.answer: This industry directly competes with offline retail industries, particularly brick-and-mortar clothing stores, department stores and big-box retailers. When consumers choose to purchase clothing in physical locations rather than online, industry revenue is negatively affected.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? How do you capitalize on this demand?
FAQs.answer: Per capita disposable income determines an individual's ability to purchase goods or services. Higher per capita disposable income lets consumers spend more on discretionary items, like clothing items and increases industry revenue.

FAQs.question: Do you find revenue trends to be in line with the number of mobile internet connections? How can you take advantage of this increased online traffic?
FAQs.answer: The number of broadband connections in the United States represents the total number of internet connections with a speed over 200 kilobits per second in at least one direction. As the number of broadband connections increases, more individuals have access to purchase items online.
